News

News quiz: Test your knowledge of this week in Berkeley news

Did you follow the news in Berkeley this week, Oct. 14-19? To take our quiz, choose an answer, and the correct response will appear after you click.

By Anjali Shrivastava and May Cui and Vanessa Qian
OCTOBER 19, 2018

1.

Members of which UC Berkeley fraternity recently faced controversy after jokingly posing for a picture with sexual assault protesters?

Phi Gamma Delta Delta Kappa Epsilon Sigma Chi Chi Psi

Correct!

Not quite!

Campus senior Walker Spence posted a photo that was privately distributed among the Phi Gamma Delta, or Fiji, group chat on Facebook. Spence said in an email that he was spurred to create the post after his housemate, a member of Fiji, sent him the picture.

Read more: Members of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity jokingly posed with sexual assault protestors, photo shows

2.

Which Berkeley City Council candidate generated confusion by claiming they are the “1st Asian Candidate” for City Council in 40 years?

Alfred Twu Cecilia “Ces” Rosales Rigel Robinson William Shei

Correct!

Not quite!

Rosales explained that she was inspired by Ying Lee, the only Asian American to serve on Berkeley City Council in about 40 years. Candidates running in 2018 other than Rosales also identify as Asian American, and Randy Gee and William Shei — who both identified as Asian American — ran for the District 7 seat in the 1990s.

Read more: Berkeley City Council candidate Cecilia Rosales’ campaign materials stir controversy

3.

A union representing UC librarians has been in contract negotiations with the UC system for how long?

1 month 3 months 6 months 1 year

Correct!

Not quite!

The University Council-American Federation of Teachers, or UC-AFT, has been negotiating with the UC system for higher salaries and sabbatical leave, among other demands. Currently, UC librarians are paid lower salaries than those employed by the California State University system and California community colleges.

Read more: UC librarians begin contract negotiations for higher salaries

4.

A UC Berkeley study found that low-income Bay Area residents tend to migrate toward which part of California?

Los Angeles San Diego Sacramento San Jose

Correct!

Not quite!

According to the study, low-income Bay Area residents are increasingly limited to the more affordable parts of California for housing. This greatly lowers their access to education options and employment, “marginalizing them economically,” the study said.

Read more: Study finds racial, economic disparities in migration out of Bay Area

5.

Which UC Berkeley professor will testify on behalf of Harvard University in a lawsuit over affirmative action?

Robert Reich Christina Romer Martha Olney David Card

Correct!

Not quite!

Harvard University will defend its admissions process using UC Berkeley economics professor David Card’s research, which ultimately found no evidence that Harvard intentionally discriminates against Asian American students. Card is expected to testify against the complainants’ claim that Asian Americans must outperform students from other minority groups to gain admission into Harvard.

Read more: UC Berkeley professor to serve as key witness for Harvard University in admissions lawsuit

6.

Berkeley Lab researchers recently discovered that which Egyptian pigment can boost energy efficiency?

Blue Green Red Yellow

Correct!

Not quite!

The ancient pigment can enhance energy efficiency by cooling rooftops and walls and could potentially be applied to the generation of solar energy, according to Berkeley Lab researchers. The research confirmed that the pigment’s fluorescence, which serves to cool the surface that is absorbing the light, can be 10 times stronger than was previously thought.

Read more: Berkeley Lab researchers find ancient pigment can improve energy efficiency

7.

The City of Berkeley will be providing how many storage lockers for homeless individuals?

42 36 58 15

Correct!

Not quite!

The program provides lockers with 9 cubic feet of storage space that are accessible on a first-come, first-served basis. Berkeley City Council approved a contract with BOSS on July 24 and agreed to allocate $50,000 to fund the program.

Read more: City of Berkeley launches program providing storage lockers for homeless individuals

8.

How many photograph(s) were stolen from an exhibit at UC Berkeley School of Law’s Human Rights Center?

One Two Four Six

Correct!

Not quite!

Alexey Berlind, the Human Rights Center’s programs administrator, said that on Monday morning, employees from the Human Rights Center noticed that four of the photographs — two smaller portraits and two larger images from three different walls — were missing.

Read more: Photographs of genocide victims stolen from Berkeley Law’s Human Rights Center

9.

Which UC Berkeley alum will be working with Bancroft Library’s oral history project?

Jerry Brown Steve Wozniak Chris Pine Jesse Arreguín

Correct!

Not quite!

The Oral History Center conducts interviews with themes ranging from science and business to politics and arts, among others. Gov. Jerry Brown’s interview is expected to touch on topics including his experience as California governor and his time as secretary of state, among other topics.

Read more: Oral history center to interview outgoing Gov. Jerry Brown

10.

Berkeley City Council passed an ordinance requiring that personal belongings can not be left unattended on the street for how long?

More than two hours More than six hours More than 12 hours One day

Correct!

Not quite!

The regulation seeks to make sidewalks safer and more accessible to pedestrians by prohibiting personal objects, including those owned by homeless individuals, on residential sidewalks and limiting them in commercial and manufacturing districts.

Read more: City Council passes sidewalk ordinance, installs cameras for San Pablo Park
